chapter.title: Main Menu
chapter.para: The main menu is where you do high-level tasks in LOGO, such as loading a LOGO program, loading an BITMAP image, setting up a printer, or even reading this help file.

section.title: File Menu
section.para: The File menu includes commands that enable you to operate on logo procedure files. Note that, as a side effect, any selection in this menu that has a directory in its dialog box will effectively change to that directory as the current working directory. For more information, select the File menu command name.

section.title: File-New Command
section.para: This will clear (DELETE, PURGE, ZAP) all procedures currently loaded in memory. It's like starting with a "new" session.

section.title: File-Load Command
section.para: This allows you to load in procedures from disk into memory so that they can be executed or edited. See also the LOAD command.

section.title: File-Save Command
section.para: This allows you to save everything that is loaded in memory onto the disk. See also the SAVE command.

section.title: File-Save As Command
section.para: This is the same as the File-Save command, except that it prompts you for a filename.

section.title: File-Edit Command
section.para: This is how you edit procedures that have already been loaded (or developed) in memory. You will be prompted with all existing procedures (currently loaded within memory) and you can also enter a new one. See also the EDIT command.

section.title: File-Erase Command
section.para: This is how you erase procedures that have already been loaded (or developed) in memory. You will be prompted with all existing procedures (currently loaded within memory). See also the ERASE command.

section.title: File-Exit Command
section.para: This is how you exits MSWLogo. See also the BYE command.

section.title: Bitmap Menu
section.para: The Bitmap menu includes commands that enable you to operate on bitmap files.

section.title: Bitmap-New Command
section.para: This will clear the work done on the screen and create a new environment to save things in.

section.title: Bitmap-Load Command
section.para: This allows you to read in an image you already saved in the past. The format of the file you save things in, is known as, a Microsoft Windows Bitmap (.BMP). You can interchange these files with other applications such as Paint. Note that these files can be BIG and can take a while to read or write. Also see the BITLOAD command.
See also the section on using color.

section.title: Bitmap-Save Command
section.para: This allows you to save a PICTURE (bitmap image) of your work on the computer's disk so that the computer will not forget it. It also allows you to add more work to an existing piece of work. Remember, if your image was generated with a LOGO program you really don't need to save it as an image unless you want to use the image in another application such as Paint or as a wallpaper. Also see the BITSAVE command.

The format of the file you save things in, is known as, a Microsoft Windows Bitmap (.BMP). You can interchange these files with other applications such as Paint. Note that these files can be BIG and can take a while to read or write.
See also the SETACTIVEAREA command.

section.title: Bitmap-Save As Command
section.para: This is the same as Bitmap-Save Command, but prompts your for a new file name.

section.title: Bitmap-Active Area Command
section.para: This allows you to select the work area to be printed or saved. The primary purpose of this option is performance and space. You no longer need to wait for the software to build a full image. It takes less time and less memory to print and disk space to save a partial image. As a side effect you can adjust where your image ends up on the page by selecting different extents. You may at anytime click on reset to put the extents back to the full image. MSWLogo will remember what you set them to even after you exit.

This command also allows you to set how many "Turtle Pixels" are mapped to an Inch on your printout. The default is 125 Turtle Pixels per inch of paper. Since MSWLogo's workspace defaults to 1000x1000 turtle pixels, that equates to about 8x8 inches (1000/125x1000/125). You may increase this number to take advantage of higher resolution printers but your image will become smaller. You can compensate for this by increasing your work space (and you're drawing size).
You can also set the active area with the Logo command SETACTIVEAREA and obtain it with the Logo command ACTIVEAREA.

section.title: Bitmap-Print Setup Command
section.para: This allows you to setup your printer before you print.

section.title: Bitmap-Print Command
section.para: This allows you to print the contents of the screen.

section.title: Set Menu
section.para: The Set menu allows you to change some of the characteristics of how LOGO behaves when drawing.

section.title: Set-Pen Size Command
section.para: This command allows you to select the pen size in which the turtle will draw. You can also select the pen size with the Logo command SETPENSIZE and obtain it with the Logo command PENSIZE.

section.title: Set-Label Font Command
section.para: This command allows you to select the font in which the command LABEL will draw with. You can also select the font with the Logo command SETLABELFONT and obtain it with the Logo command LABELFONT.

section.title: Set-Commander Font Command
section.para: This command allows you to choose the Commander's Font. The chosen font will remain selected even after MSWLogo has been restarted.

section.title: Set-Pen Color Command
section.para: This command allows you to select the pen color. You can also select the pen color with the Logo command SETPENCOLOR and obtain it with the Logo command PENCOLOR.

section.title: Set-Flood Color Command
section.para: This command allows you to select the flood color in which the turtle will FILL. You can also select the flood color with the Logo command SETFLOODCOLOR and obtain it with the Logo command FLOODCOLOR.

section.title: Set-Screen Color Command
section.para: This command allows you to select the screen color. You can also select the screen color with the Logo command SETSCREENCOLOR and obtain it with the Logo command SCREENCOLOR.

section.title: Zoom Menu
section.para: The Zoom menu allows you set the zoom factor. You can also set the zoom factor with the Logo command ZOOM.

section.title: Zoom-In Command
section.para: This command doubles the current zoom factor.

section.title: Zoom-Out Command
section.para: This command halves the current zoom factor.

section.title: Zoom-Normal Command
section.para: This command restores the zoom factor to 1.0 (no zooming).

section.title: Help Menu
section.para: The Help menu allows you to learn more about LOGO. For more information, select the Help menu command name. Also see the HELP command.

section.title: Help-Index Command
section.para: This command puts you in Microsoft Windows Help for LOGO..

section.title: Help-MCI
section.para: This puts you into the MCI help file. It explains the syntax of the arguments to the MCI command.

section.title: Help-Demo Command
section.para: This runs the DEMO program from the Logo library.

section.title: Help-Tutorial Command
section.para: This brings you to the tutorial section in the help menu.

section.title: Help-Examples Command
section.para: This brings you to an HTML page that describes each example program that comes with MSWLogo.

section.title: Help-Release Notes Command
section.para: This displays the release notes for this release of MSWLogo.

section.title: Help-About Logo Command
section.para: This displays the copyright and version information for MSWLogo.

section.title: Help-About MS Command
section.para: This displays information on Multiple Scelerosis.
